TagDef: Related to how the service is architected and likely where any work to fix would require changes to the architecture of the service
The current architecture does not allow for the most blast radius reduction, or there is another issue related to the blast radius of the impact
Related to the lack of or insufficient caching patterns or the presence of any caching anti-patterns
An issue related to cold start

This is a placeholder for any configuration related issue that is not covered in the above tags. The outages assigned under this should be reviewed periodically so that meaningful tags can be created and assigned as needed.
Related to the way a database was integrated into the overall architecture or design of the service or specific scenario
A change to the database was a factor
An issue related database deadlocks
The settings for the database(s) were inconsistent, leading to a runtime situation where different behavior existed for the instance(s)
There is a limitation in the current design of the service that prevents that part of the architecture to adequately perform it's role or be changed to adapt to new conditions
An issue related to missing design review

An issue related to an architectural condition that creates a possible Denial of Service, but not necessarily one related to increased load

The client failed because it was unable to get a certificate or it’s chain. If the service is using the platform (AKV / dSMS + KV VM ext / ACMS Agent + OneCert), then it’s our problem to fix. If the service is using their own cert distribution solution or cert binding solution, then it’s the service’s problem
Human error resulted in the a bad cert, a cert with missing properties, a cert from an unsupported PKI.
The client fails because it is not able to validate the revocation status of a certificate. This is usually because the CRL or OCSP endpoints that contain the revocation status are unreachable.

Any time a client expects the certificate to have a specific value but it doesn’t. This could be thumbprint pinning, it could be a specific subject name or serial number, or any other property of the certificate

This should be applied to instances when the outage was caused because the code version was not compatible with the configuration version e.g. During deployment to 4 regions one of the region had older code but the new configurations were deployed causing outage for that region since the configuration and the code were not compatible.
Parser could not parse the config file

Local configuration overrides are directly deployed creating drift between the as-built (the configuration deployed) and the configuration in the base systems of record e.g. someone made direct changes to the production config file but those changes were never merged into the master copy causing those changes to be overwritten when next configuration updates are deployed.

This is used to indicate there is another incident that is responsible, so while we track this incident the tags are assigned to the other incident that is responsible
Any issue caused by the service not being able to handle changes in load
The outage was caused because the service to fetch the configuration could not handle the load and it failed causing the outage.
An issue related to a condition where increased load results in a Denial of Service
An issue related to the sudden increase in load, but not sustained load
An issue related to the sudden increase in load caused by a single customer, but not sustained load
The service lacked capacity to handle load
The service did not have an adequate retry strategy or implementation for when client's retry requests against it
Related to increasing or decreasing capacity according to load
The service's current autoscaling practice or functionality is not sufficient to handle increasing load
The service does not automatically increase capacity when subject to increasing load
The service does not properly throttle incoming requests, or does not behave properly when being throttled
All operations MUST expose a normalized resource cost.
The service lacked telemetry to know when it was throttling or being throttled
Excess load from one tenant negatively impacted another tenant despite having throttling
Current throttling mechanism is not a token bucket based algorithm or is otherwise not developed using proven practices

All services MUST be able to override throttling behavior, to handle inrush (slowly dialing up overall capacity during recovery conditions), with specific capabilities for whitelisting/blacklisting operations and users/tenants/subscriptions/etc. via direct token replenishment or bypassing quota enforcement
Services need to be aware of upstream calling patterns, and whether successful user outcomes require a minimum sequence of operations.
The service does not have any throttling of incoming requests
All services MUST be able to handle non-uniformity in their user facing throttling scopes, in an appropriately scalable and manageable fashion

All services need to align throttling scopes against the throttling blast radius to minimize impact of noisy neighbors, even within an individual customer scope (e.g. a single misbehaved script cannot lock a customer out of management of an entire subscription).

Services must NOT implement “tar pit” throttling approaches, where they delay response for a period of time in order to reduce the volume of incoming work (or hold processing the request until the throttling period has passed).  Instead, services must be prepared to immediately respond with the appropriate throttling codes (e.g. 429) on a transient or enduring basis (blacklisting).
The service was throttled, and did not handle it correctly
The service has throttling, but it is insufficient and there can be or was impact
The service is not sending the correct response code when it is throttled or throttling clients
